Subject: Re: [neat] Another note on activation

Darren Izzard wrote:
> 
> The way it worked was, each evaluation, the contents of each node in
> the chain was passing one link further down it. So, the input to a
> delay line of five nodes would appear at the other end after five
> timesteps.
> 
> It's surprising that this could take the place of recurrent
> connections, and indeed probably only works in limited circumstances,
> but it did nonetheless solve the problem.

Hi Darren,

Thanks for jumping into the conversation.

Unfortunately, this doesn't add up.  In a purely feed-forward network, 
the excitation at the inputs should propagate all the way through to the 
outputs.  In fact, in my definition of such a network, they *must* 
propagate through.  It may not be biologically correct?  But, 
algorithmically, structurally, and graphically, it seems correct to me.

Given that, then how could such a network possibly have any memory (or 
time delay)?

This type of network should be completely deterministic.  If you present 
a set of inputs to it, you will always get the a specific set of outputs 
-- no matter how many times you present it, or in which order, etc.

Since I don't question your experience, I've tried to come up with how 
this could have possibly worked.  The only thing that comes to my mind 
is this...

... if you were doing the iterative-unordered network activation 
algorithm (as used in Ken's original source code), then perhaps you 
weren't actually fully getting your inputs propagated through the entire 
network?  Particularly larger, more complicated networks (similar to the 
solutions you got).  This could especially be true if you were iterating 
a fixed number of times (N).  [If you only update a network, in 
arbitrary order, say 10 times, but have a network of large depth (say 
1000), then yah, I can see how the whole network would be time delayed.]

In this case, if your solution *required* recurrent connections, and you 
had been completely (by definition) updating your forward only networks, 
then NEAT could never converge.

That NEAT works in all of these cases reinforces the obvious (to us) 
power in these evolutionary methods.  They evolve not only to the 
problem space, but also to our different algorithmic interpretations.

--Steve
